Award.AwardTitle: Generalized Transport Models in Earth Surface Dynamics: Novel Experiments for Demonstrating and Quantifying Non-local Transport
Award.AbstractNarration:
Generalized Transport Models in Earth Surface Dynamics: Novel Experiments for Demonstrating and Quantifying Non-local Transport
Vaughan Voller, Efi Foufoula-Georgiou, Kimberly Hill, Chris Paola
University of Minnesota
EAR-1318593

ABSTRACT
Understanding the transport of environmental fluxes, such as sediment, tracers, particulates, and pollutants, on the Earth?s surface is paramount for building accurate models of geomorphic transport, quantifying landscape evolution under natural and human-induced changes and for inferring past surface conditions from interpretation of the stratigraphic record. Historically, geomorphic transport models have expressed particulate or sediment flux in terms of instantaneous local properties, such as gradients in the surface elevation or local velocities. Accurate models of sediment and particulate transport in rivers, hillslopes, and deltaic systems are at the heart of Earth surface Dynamics research as well as of practical significance in guiding environmental management based on accurate predictive models. The increasing awareness of the heterogeneity and connectivity of Earth systems has led to new theoretical constructs which embrace non-locality and collective behavior in geomorphic transport. The proposed novel and simple experimental systems promise to provide the first unambiguous evidence of the role of non-local transport in sediment and particulate regimes. Linking the results of these experiments to the evaluation of non-local and anomalous diffusion properties will allow researchers to more confidently predict when to use non-local models and which parameters to use in these models. This information will have a transformative impact on our ability to understand the transport of sediment particles that shape and control the evolution of the Earth-surface environment. The proposed experiments are novel and will be constructed using 3-D printing technology. PIs also propose to prototype ?toy experimental? systems that will provide zero set-up time desktop demonstrations of anomalous diffusion behaviors. Their plan is to disseminate these systems through the current NCED educational and museum contacts, and specifically advance the development of a prototype exhibit at the Science Museum of Minnesota, a long-time partner of NCED.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The spreading of a blob of dyed water on a kitchen tissue, the expansion of cities, the seepage of surface water into soil, the melting of ice, the formation of landscapes and many similar processes can be described by what is know as a diffusion model, where the spreading in the medium (tissue, landscape, soil) is directed along the slope (gradient) of the system potential (concentration of dye, population, water pressure). In normal diffusion systems the length scale L of the spreading (radius of blob, depth of moist soil), changes with the square root of time t, i.e., L~ t(1/2) (exponent n = 1/2). When there are irregularities (heterogeneities) in the medium (grease spots on the kitchen tissue, inhabitable areas, fissures in the soil) however, "hold ups" and "fast paths" can result in so called "anomalous" diffusion where the spreading at a particular point is controlled by non-local conditions remote from that point The result of this non-local control is that the nature of the spreading length scale changes, exhibiting a time exponent n that differs from 1/2. 

 

While there are many examples of physical and natural systems that are known to exhibit anomalous diffusion there are few if any simple demonstrations of such behavior and, further, the connection between the medium heterogeneity and the resulting time exponent value is not fully understood.  In this light, the core objective of our research is two fold. (1) To establish bench scale experiments to clearly demonstrate how the presence of heterogeneity in a diffusion system can lead to anomalous behavior. (2) Explore how geometric measures of the heterogeneity in a given system might be related to the spreading time exponent n. Our signature experiment centers on the pressure driven seepage of glycerin into a thin horizontal cavity (~2mm) formed by two-closely spaced plates (100x100mm in plan view dimension), a system known as a Hele-Shaw cell. We regard this setup as an analog for the seepage of surface water into porous soils. The presence of heterogeneity is introduced into the experiment by placing 3D printed obstacle fields into the cavity.

 

With this simple bench scale system we have arrived at a way to unambiguously demonstrate how the presence of the appropriate form of heterogeneity will result in anomalous diffusion behavior. In particular, we show that when no obstacle field is present or the plan-view obstacle field forms a repeating pattern, at a scale below the Hele-Shaw plate dimensions, the seepage of fluid into the cell follows a normal diffusion behavior, i.e., the effective depth of seepage goes as the square root of time t.  On the other hand, when the plan-view obstacle field is a fractal carpet, which has no repeating pattern, "hold ups" in the seepage lead to a clear observation of anomalous sub-diffusion, i.e., the time exponent (power n) in the effective depth of seepage vs. time relationship is significantly less that 1/2. Depending on the fractal dimension of the carpet we have experimentally observed exponents in the range 0.33 to 0.42; values that have been confirmed through direct computer simulations. Further, by using the results from our experiments and accompanying direct computer simulations we have been able to establish some basic relationships between the fractal dimension of the carpet pattern and the observed values of the anomalous time exponent.

 

Our simple experiment and its interpretation provides us with a tool for understanding how, across a wide range of natural and physical processes, the normal diffusion spreading to the square root of time might be disrupted by the presence of the correct form of heterogeneity.
